help.title: Dot Plot
help.body:
Description
A dot plot is a type of chart used to display the distribution of a dataset using dots. It’s simple but effective, especially for smaller datasets or for showing individual data points clearly. A dot plot places a dot for each data point along an axis (usually the x-axis), stacking them vertically to avoid overlap. It's a good alternative to histograms or bar charts when precision and visibility of individual values are important. Each dot represents one observation. Dots are stacked to show frequency.

Usage
ggplot(data= dataset, aes(x=x_var))+ geom_dotplot( aes(fill = group_var), #optional. Omitted if there is no grouping variable selected method = "histodot", binwidth = 0.1, stackdir = "up", #stackup_points_direction dotsize = 0.8, binaxis = "x", stackratio = 4, #stackratio_spread_points color = NA )​

Package
ggplot2;ggthemes;stringr
